boyfrnd007 wrote:

>    Thanks for your help. But the thing is this is application that I
> am trying to test and they need something automated to run it. These
> microsoft documents can change with date and can remain same for
> months. 

 > Everytime this document changes, there is a mail in my
> mailbox having the document.

There's a test.

testSendWhenDocumentChanges
     simulate document changing
     assert that the object tried to send the document

Sounds like a simple event/listener design.

> I have made a test document in the
> database, that everday its date changes so I get one document in my
> mailbox, but with different date.  

Why does the document have to arrive at your inbox? Why not just check 
whether the application tries to send the document somewhere?

> But scanning a mailbox to find
> one mail can be hard? 

Why do you think you need to do this?

> The other properties I would like to test is
> am i getting the right document back? A document can be sent in
> various formats, like HTML, OR word. I want to make sure if the
> format is right..

Why does it matter what the format of the document is? I'm guessing 
what's important is that you send the right document at the right time 
for the right reasons.

That's three behaviors:

  1. When I send a document, I send the right one.
  2. I choose to send a document when I /need/ to send a document.
  3. When X, Y and Z happen, I try to send a document.

Pick one and test it without worrying about the others. For example, the 
first is probably easiest: write a test that checks whether the code 
that sends the document sends the /right/ document.
